Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative research: Mathematics of emerging imaging methods in medicine and homeland security
Award.AbstractNarration:
Computerized tomography plays a central role in biomedical imaging. Tomography techniques are also extensively used for industrial non-destructive testing, in geology and geophysics, astronomy, and in other areas. Lately, they have found important applications in homeland security. Over the last decades, several modalities have been developed and have became standard. Such are, for instance, the traditional X-ray CT scan, SPECT, MRI, Optical-, Ultrasound-, and Electrical Impedance Tomography, to name a few. However, such tasks as detection of small cancerous tumors in soft tissues or finding a small amount of nuclear material in a large container still present a significant challenge. In recent years, revolutionary "hybrid" or "multi-physics" methods of medical imaging have been emerging. By combining two or three different types of waves (or physical fields) these methods overcome limitations of classical tomography techniques and deliver otherwise unavailable, potentially life-saving diagnostic information - at a lesser cost and with less health hazard to a patient. As a rule, the images in these modalities are obtained by complex mathematical procedures, rather than through direct acquisition. The corresponding mathematics is, mostly, at very early stages of development. Thus, the first part of the project addresses the central mathematical and numerical issues in several of the novel hybrid techniques, based on combinations of magnetic, electric, acoustic, and optical waves, and the general mathematical issues common to all of these techniques. The second part of the projects is directed toward the improvement of the known methods and development of new tomographic techniques for homeland security problems. In particular, we will focus on the detection techniques for illicit weapons-grade nuclear materials in cargo, to be used at border crossings and harbors. In the third part these techniques will be used to resolve some outstanding problems in Synthetic Aperture Radar applications, radio tomography, ultrasound reflectometry, and other areas.


The goal of the project is to develop new techniques of medical imaging, as well as efficient methods of detecting illicit nuclear materials at border crossings and in harbors. The project will have a significant impact on the development and implementation of several new sensitive, inexpensive, and safe methods of biomedical imaging, efficient techniques of nuclear threat detection in homeland security, with applications in several other areas of imaging and non-destructive industrial testing (e.g., synthetic aperture radar). The results will be disseminated through publications in high quality research journals, presentations at national and international conferences, and series of lectures at various venues. Graduate students will play a significant role in the project, which will prepare them for work in the exciting area at the junction of exact sciences, medicine, biology, and homeland security. Parts of the study resulted from the project will be delivered in graduate level classes, lecture series at national and international schools and conferences, and in two monographs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project addressed two imaging areas:

  1. Medical diagnostic imaging. 
  2. Homeland security imaging for detecting small amounts of illicit nuclear materials at border crossings and harbors.

In the first one, several novel imaging techniques have been suggested recently. These directed toward the noble goal of developing safer, cheaper, and high quality diagnostic imaging modalities. As in most cases in tomography, a large part of the problem is to develop mathematical procedures of recovering the image from the signals obtained from the newly built scanner. This applies in particular to the so called coupled physics (or hybrid) methods, such as for instance thermo-acoustic imaging, where electromagnetic and ultrasound waves cooperate to provide high resolution diagnostic images, where tumors can be readily seen. There are several others: acousto-elastic, acousto-electric, etc. techniques.

The mathematics of these modalities has experienced recently fast development. The results of the project (development, analysis, and implementation of new algorithms, as well as detailed study of the features of the relevant mathematical procedures) are well known already and contributed significantly to the development of hybrid techniques. 

Another novel theme arises from the well-established and widely used medical imaging technique SPECT (single photon emission computer tomography), where the problem lies in a much weaker signal and stronger noise than, for instance, in the X-ray CT. To fight this problem, which also arises in astronomy, a novel so called Compton camera has been proposed, which provides much better signal. Alas, the mathematics required has not been developed. In this project, a detailed pioneering study of all important issues has been conducted: image reconstruction algorithms, their analytic features and computer implementation, the role of the geometry of the camera, etc. Numerical experiments with SPECT data show that these algorithms can tolerate much higher levels of noise than could have been expected.

The situation with border security detection of small amounts of illicit nuclear materials is similar to SPECT, but in a much worse incarnation: the signal can be a hundred, or even thousand times smaller than the noise. The situation, seemingly hopeless, can be in fact dealt with using Compton cameras. However, here the techniques mentioned above for SPECT fail miserably. The results of the project explain why and provide different, statistical-analytic, as well as deep learning algorithms that indeed do the job. 

To disseminate the results of the project, many invited lectures and series of lectures were given in the USA and around the world. A monograph and several surveys are published, as well as many research articles. A graduate class was taught, as well as a class for advanced high school students during a summer camp. Four graduate students have been involved into the project, with two PhD theses and one MS already completed.
